paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Objective:** Become familiar with running K-Nearest Neighbors on Spark
**File locations:** spark-labs/weatherAUS.csv
**Successful outcome:** Calculate the nearest neighbors to predict if it will rain tomorrow
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Supervised learning, K-Nearest Neighbors

---

%md
# Setup
---

paragraphs.title: Retrieve the data from internet and store it in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh

rm -f weatherAUS.csv
wget -nc -P /home/zeppelin https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/sci-241/rattle-togaware-weather/weatherAUS.csv
hdfs dfs -rm spark-labs/weatherAUS.csv
hdfs dfs -put weatherAUS.csv spark-labs/

paragraphs.title: Import libraries
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import udf, monotonically_increasing_id
from pyspark.sql.types import ArrayType, FloatType
from pyspark.sql.functions import col
from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler, StringIndexer
from pyspark.sql.window import Window
from pyspark.sql.functions import row_number
from pyspark.sql.functions import mean, round
from pyspark.ml.evaluation import MulticlassClassificationEvaluator as MCE

%md
# Lab
---

%md
## Load and inspect the data

%md
First we need to load the data into a dataframe using the 'header' and 'inferSchema' options.

paragraphs.title: 1 - Load the data into a Spark DataFrame

paragraphs.text:
%md
When doing machine learning, it is important to look at the data you are working with
Use z.show(data) to view the first 20 rows of your data

paragraphs.title: 2 - Inspect the data

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Transform the DataFrame into one usable by Spark ML

Spark contains many helper functions, like StringIndexer to convert categorical variables to numerical ones.
We will define a function process_data that does all this, and then assembles the data for us.

%md

Copy and paste the code below in the next paragraph
~~~
def process_data(data):    
    non_null = data.na.drop(how="any")
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindGustDir',outputCol = 'WindGustDir_indexed')
    indexed1 = indexer.fit(non_null).transform(non_null)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindDir9am', outputCol = 'WindDir9am_indexed')
    indexed2 = indexer.fit(indexed1).transform(indexed1)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindDir3pm', outputCol = 'WindDir3pm_indexed')
    indexed3 = indexer.fit(indexed2).transform(indexed2)
    
    indexed = indexed3.drop('WindGustDir','WindDir9am','WindDir3pm')
    
    feature_columns = list(filter(lambda x: 'Temp' in x or 'WindGust' in x or '9am' in x or '3pm' in x,indexed.columns))

    assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=feature_columns, outputCol="features")

    # Transform the data into a form useable by SParkML
    vectorized = assembler.transform(indexed)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = "RainTomorrow", outputCol = 'label')
    labeled  = indexer.fit(vectorized).transform(vectorized)
    return labeled
~~~

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create the process_data function

paragraphs.text:
%md

In the next cell, call process_data on the data we read in.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Call the process_data on our data

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
We are going to be using the cosine distance to determine the nearest neighbors.
Part of this measurement requires to know the magnitude, or norm of the vector.
To save time, we will calculate this once for each row.
Copy and paste the code below in the next paragraph.

~~~
def get_norm(v):
  return float(v.norm(2))

get_norm_udf = udf(get_norm, FloatType())
cleaned_data = cleaned_data.withColumn('norm', get_norm_udf('features')).withColumn('id', monotonically_increasing_id())
z.show(cleaned_data.select('id','norm'))
~~~

paragraphs.title: 5 - Calculate the norm
6 - Show the label and features columns

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
This is the data that we will feed to our machine learning algorithm.

%md
## Train a model

%md
Next we need to split this data between a training and a testing set.
We will keep 
* 99.98 % of the rows for training and save the other 0.02% for testing on and
* use a seed of 228 that will help everyone in the class have similar results.

Any larger test set and we could not complete the lab in a reasonable time

paragraphs.title: 7 - Split the data into training and test instances

paragraphs.text:
%md

The cartesian product will give us one row for each pair of training and test set instance
To keep the columns separate in each row, type the following to rename the columns

~~~
replacements_train = {c:c + '_train' for c in train.columns}
replacements_test = {c:c + '_test' for c in test.columns}

train = train.select([col(c).alias(replacements_train.get(c, c)) for c in train.columns])
test = test.select([col(c).alias(replacements_test.get(c, c)) for c in test.columns])

train.printSchema()
test.printSchema()
~~~

paragraphs.title: 8 - Rename the columns of the training and test sets

paragraphs.text:
%md
Type the code below to calculate the cartesian product and give each row a unique ID
~~~
cartesian = train.crossJoin(test).cache()
cartesian =  cartesian.withColumn('joint_id',monotonically_increasing_id())
~~~

paragraphs.title: 9 - Calculate the cartesian product

paragraphs.text:
%md

Run the following code in the next paragraph
~~~
scored = cartesian.join(
    cartesian.rdd.map(lambda x: (float(x['features_train'].dot(x['features_test'])/(x['norm_train'] * x['norm_test'])),x['joint_id'] )).toDF().withColumnRenamed('_2',"joint_id"),
    on = 'joint_id'
)
~~~


This performs the distance calculate for each row in the cartesian product and then adds the information as a column to the data
It may take a minute or two to run

paragraphs.title: 10 - Calculate the distance between each pair of training and test instances

paragraphs.text:
%md
For each point in the test set let us find the K-closest points in the training data.
For this, we need a window object that we can use to work on sections of the data
~~~
window = Window.partitionBy(scored['id_test']).orderBy(scored['_1'].desc())
K = 5
k_nearest = scored.select(col('*'), row_number().over(window).alias('row_number')).where(col('row_number') <= K)
~~~

paragraphs.title: 11 - Remove all but the top K pairs for each point in the test set

paragraphs.text:
%md
Find the mean classification of the K-nearest training points
~~~
predictions = k_nearest.groupby('id_test').agg(mean('label_train').alias('raw_prediction'),mean('label_test').alias('label'))
z.show(predictions)
~~~

paragraphs.title: 12 - Make a prediction

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Round the average to either 0 or 1 to get a discrete label
~~~
predictions = predictions.withColumn('prediction',round('raw_prediction')).cache()
~~~

paragraphs.title: 13 - Round the average to get a discrete label

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create an MulticlassClassificationEvaluator (MCE) object and print out the F1 measure
~~~
evaluator = MCE()
print(evaluator.evaluate(predictions))
~~~
You should see a value of 0.8915975158264684.

paragraphs.title: 14 - Create an MCE object and print out the F1 measure
15 - Visualize the predictions

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Bonus
paragraphs.text:
%md
If you have extra time, try to improve your model.
* Go back to step 3 and change the features used in your model
* Go back to step 10 in the notebook and change the value of K
* After editing that cell, run the entire notebook again by hitting the play button at the top

%md
# Result
**You have now:** You have now successfully used K-nearest neighbors and evaluated it using the F1 score.

---

%md
# Solution
---

paragraphs.title: 1 - Load the data into a Spark DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

data = spark.read.format('csv').option('header',True).option('inferSchema',True).option('nullValue',"NA").load('spark-labs/weatherAUS.csv')

paragraphs.title: 2 - Inspect the data
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

z.show(data)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create the process_data function
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

def process_data(data):    
    non_null = data.na.drop(how="any")
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindGustDir',outputCol = 'WindGustDir_indexed')
    indexed1 = indexer.fit(non_null).transform(non_null)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindDir9am', outputCol = 'WindDir9am_indexed')
    indexed2 = indexer.fit(indexed1).transform(indexed1)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindDir3pm', outputCol = 'WindDir3pm_indexed')
    indexed3 = indexer.fit(indexed2).transform(indexed2)
    
    indexed = indexed3.drop('WindGustDir','WindDir9am','WindDir3pm')
    
    feature_columns = list(filter(lambda x: 'Temp' in x or 'WindGust' in x or '9am' in x or '3pm' in x,indexed.columns))

    assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=feature_columns, outputCol="features")

    # Transform the data into a form useable by SParkML
    vectorized = assembler.transform(indexed)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = "RainTomorrow", outputCol = 'label')
    labeled  = indexer.fit(vectorized).transform(vectorized)
    return labeled

paragraphs.title: 4 - Call the process_data on our data
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

cleaned_data = process_data(data)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 5 - Calculate the norm

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 6 - Show the label and features columns
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

z.show(cleaned_data.select('label','features'))

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 7 - Split the data into training and test instances
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

train , test = cleaned_data.randomSplit([0.9998,0.002],seed=228)

paragraphs.title: 8 - Rename the columns of the training and test sets
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

replacements_train = {c:c + '_train' for c in train.columns}
replacements_test = {c:c + '_test' for c in test.columns}

train = train.select([col(c).alias(replacements_train.get(c, c)) for c in train.columns])
test = test.select([col(c).alias(replacements_test.get(c, c)) for c in test.columns])

train.printSchema()
test.printSchema()

paragraphs.title: 9 - Calculate the Cartesian product
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

cartesian = train.crossJoin(test).cache()
cartesian =  cartesian.withColumn('joint_id',monotonically_increasing_id())

paragraphs.title: 10 - Calculate the distance between each pair of training and test instances
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

scored = cartesian.join(
    cartesian.rdd.map(lambda x: (float(x['features_train'].dot(x['features_test'])/(x['norm_train'] * x['norm_test'])),x['joint_id'] )).toDF().withColumnRenamed('_2',"joint_id"),
    on = 'joint_id'
)

paragraphs.title: 11 - Remove all but the top K pairs for each point in the test set
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

window = Window.partitionBy(scored['id_test']).orderBy(scored['_1'].desc())
K = 5
k_nearest = scored.select(col('*'), row_number().over(window).alias('row_number')).where(col('row_number') <= K)

paragraphs.title: 12 - Make a prediction
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

predictions = k_nearest.groupby('id_test').agg(mean('label_train').alias('raw_prediction'),mean('label_test').alias('label'))
z.show(predictions)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 13 - Round the average to get a discrete label
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

predictions = predictions.withColumn('prediction',round('raw_prediction')).cache()

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 14 - Create an MCE object and print out the F1 measure
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

evaluator = MCE()
print(evaluator.evaluate(predictions))

paragraphs.title: 15 - Visualize the predictions
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

z.show(predictions)

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.
